text: Since inception in 1992 there have been 49 clubs who have played in the Premier League. Seven clubs have won the Premier League: Manchester United (13 times), Chelsea (five times), Manchester City (four times), Arsenal (three times), Blackburn Rovers (once), Leicester City (once) and Liverpool (once). ==Record of finishing positions of clubs in the Premier League== Table correct as at the end of the 2019-20 Premier League season. {| class="wikitable" for the UEFA Cup Winners' Cup |- |style="width:10px;background-color:#c0ea00"| ||Qualified for the UEFA Intertoto Cup |- |style="width:10px;background-color:#afeeee"| ||Premier League club, but did not qualify for any European tournament |- |style="width:10px"| • ||Absent from the list of clubs that participated in that season's Premier League |} {| class="wikitable" style="text- align:left;font-size:85%" |- |style="width:20px"| Italics ||Indicates that the team qualified for a European tournament that season, but not based upon the performance in the Premier League. The superscript identifies the route used for European qualification. |- |style="width:20px"| RED ||Indicates that the team were relegated from the Premier League to the EFL Championship. |} Chelsea won the 2011–12 UEFA Champions League, pursuant to the rules in effect at the time, only four clubs from the Premier League could play in the Champions League. This meant that Tottenham, who would usually qualify for the Champions League with a 4th place Premier League finish, were relegated to the 2012–13 UEFA Europa League instead. Originally Portsmouth qualified for the third qualifying round of the UEFA Europa League as FA Cup runners-up, replacing the Champions League-qualified Chelsea. However, they failed to apply for a UEFA license. Therefore, Liverpool took their place.
